PRE-MARKET JAPANESE & SOUTH KOREAN STOCK NEWS: Yaskawa Electric (6506 JT) FY net JPY 14.5bln vs. Prev. JPY 41.2bln Y/Y
content:
AUSTRALIA (CLOSED) 

HT&E (HT1 AT) - Reports note chatter that the Co. could be seeking a merger with oOh!media. (Newswires)

Santos (STO AT) - Co. is expected to be the next oil name in Australia to declare a capital raise. (Newswires)

 

JAPAN

Don Quijoite (7532 JT) - Co. March same store sales fell 12.1% Y/Y. (Newswires)

J Front Retailing (3086 JT) - Co. FY net JPY 21.3bln vs. Prev. JPY 27.4bln Y/Y. (Newswires)

Yaskawa Electric (6506 JT) - Co. FY net JPY 14.5bln vs. Prev. JPY 41.2bln Y/Y. (Newswires)

Banks - Japan FTC is expected to request banks to reduce their interbank transfer fees. (Newswires)

Insurers - Japanese insurers are seen to raise their hedge positions to manage swings in markets. (Newswires)

Other News - Japanese PM Abe urged people do not visit night clubs and bars to curb the coronavirus outbreak. (Newswires)

 

SOUTH KOREA

Kia Motors (000270 KS) - Co. is considering suspending 3 domestic factories due to coronavirus disruptions. (Newswires)

Ssangyong Motor (003620 KS) - Co. parent Mahindra & Mahindra (MM IS) will inject KRW 40bln into the automaker to help it stay afloat. (Yonhap)

Defence Costs - US President Trump reportedly rejected an offer by South Korea to raise defence cost contribution by at least 13% and discussions are now at an impasse, according to unnamed US officials. (Newswires)

Other News - BoK may unveil lending program for brokerages this week. (Newswires)

subject: US Energy Secretary Brouilette said US could see continued declines in output and will continue efforts to open SPR for storage, adds sees US production cuts of 1.6mln-2.0mln bpd and are looking at policy options to help the oil industry
UK Chancellor Sunak told colleagues GDP may decline by as much as 30% for Q2, while Cabinet colleagues are calling for ease of restrictions, according to the Times
CORONAVIRUS WORLDWIDE CASES 1,850,286, DEATHS 114,098, RECOVERED 422,566
content:
Figures provided as of Sunday (via worldometers website) against Saturday:

 

    US total cases 559,245 (prev. 532,879), death toll 22,036 (prev. 20,577).

    ITALY total cases 156,363 (prev. 152,271), death toll 19,899 (prev. 19,468).

    SPAIN total cases 166,831 (prev. 163,027), death toll 17,209 (prev. 16,606).

    GERMANY total cases 127,854 (prev. 125,452), death toll 3,022 (prev. 2,871).

    CHINA total cases (prev. 82,052), death toll (prev. 3,339).

    FRANCE total cases 132,591 (prev. 129,654), death toll 14,393 (prev. 13,832).

    UK total cases 84,279 (prev. 78,991), death toll 10,612 (prev. 9,875).

    SWITZERLAND total cases 25,415 (prev. 25,107), death toll 1,106 (prev. 1,036)

    NETHERLANDS total cases 25,587 (prev. 24,413), death toll 2,737 (prev. 2,643).

    CANADA total cases 24,292 (prev. 23,318), death toll 713 (prev. 653).

    SOUTH KOREA total cases 10,512 (prev. 10,480), death toll 214 (prev. 211).
analysis_details:
Note

Figures are provided via worldometers thus there may be some discrepancies on figures provided against those stated from individual states.

Blank spaces are indicative of countries that have not yet updated their figures on Sunday

subject: Politico's Managing Editor tweets White House officials are scrambling to assemble a list of business leaders for Trump’s “Opening Our Country Council”, although some firms don’t want to participate after Trump's previous public spats with big companies
IMPORTANT: Newsquawk Easter Schedule
content: • The Service will resume on Sunday April 12th at 2200BST for the beginning of the Asia-Pac session and will run until Monday 13th April at 0630BST at which point the service will halt due to the closure of EU and UK markets. The service will then resume at 1300BST for the beginning of the US session with US markets subject to a regular open.

subject: ASIAN DAILY ECONOMIC RELEASE CALENDAR IS NOW AVAILABLE IN THE RESEARCH SECTION: Highlights include: Light calendar with only Japanese Money Supply scheduled, while Australia, New Zealand, Hong Kong, UK and EU markets are shut for holidays
Jittery start to futures trading as US equity futures and WTI crude prices reverse opening surge to trade near flat despite OPEC++ breakthrough
IEA says will provide update on global oil supply and demand imbalances on Wednesday, while it will provide update on plans by some consumer countries to raise strategic reserves

Canada Energy Minister says welcomes oil cut deal agreed by OPEC+ and that Canada is committed to achieving price certainty and economic stability, while gov. source says Canada did not formally commit to curtailment policy as it provinces' jurisdiction

Saudi's King Salman, Russian President Putin and US President Trump expressed comfort with the outcome of the OPEC+ meeting, while they stressed producing countries need to fulfill their responsibilities to stabilize oil markets and support global economy
analysis_details: • As a reminder, OPEC+ resolved stand-off with Mexico on Sunday and approved its largest ever oil cut in which it agreed to cuts of 9.7mln bpd for May-June.

subject: DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
CORONAVIRUS UPDATE / RESPONSES

US President Trump commented last week that he believes the US will lose substantially under 100k lives to coronavirus and that the peak could be 60k with the number of new cases flattening which suggests we could be near a peak, while there were separate comments by NIH's Fauci that US deaths may be closer to 60k rather than the 100k-200k previously touted. (Newswires)

US overtook Italy as the highest number of coronavirus deaths over the weekend in which the total death toll stateside surpassed 21k. Furthermore, Italy extended its lockdown to May 3rd and it reported 431 additional coronavirus deaths which was its lowest daily death toll since March 19th. (Newswires)

US NEC Director Kudlow said the economy should be able to re-open on a "rolling basis" in the next month or two. (FBN)

UK PM Johnson was discharged from hospital and will continue his recovery from Chequers, while he expressed optimism the UK was making progress in its attempts to combat coronavirus. (Guardian)

UK Foreign Minister Raab said won't be able to say more regarding the lockdown until late next week, while he added it is too early to lift the lockdown and the virus hasn't peaked yet. (Newswires)

A deal was reached at last week’ Eurogroup meeting regarding a EUR 550bln economic support package for countries impacted by the coronavirus in which national leaders are to decide on whether innovative financial instruments should be used to finance the recovery according to a document. Furthermore, access to ESM credit lines will be available until the coronavirus crisis is over but afterwards Euro area should remain committed to strengthening economic and financial fundamentals, while ministers sidelined the proposal by Italy, Spain and France for coronabonds/pooled borrowing. (Newswires)

 

ASIA-PAC

  • Chinese New Yuan Loans (CNY)(Mar) 2850B vs. Exp. 1800.0B (Prev. 905.7B). (Newswires)
  • Chinese Aggregate Financing (CNY)(Mar) 5150B vs. Exp. 3140B (Prev. 855.4B)
  • Chinese M2 Money Supply (Mar) Y/Y 10.1% vs. Exp. 8.8% (Prev. 8.8%)
  • Chinese CPI (Mar) Y/Y 4.3% vs. Exp. 4.8% (Prev. 5.2%)
  • Chinese PPI (Mar) Y/Y -1.5% vs. Exp. -1.1% (Prev. -0.4%)

 

UK/EU

UK-US trade talks postponed indefinitely as COVID-19 crisis put a speedy deal in doubt, while no new date was agreed after the formal start of talks in late March were cancelled. (The Telegraph)

EU Competition Commission Vestager said EU countries should purchase stakes in companies to tackle the threat of Chinese takeovers. (FT)

  • UK GDP Estimate MM (Feb) -0.1% vs. Exp. 0.1% (Prev. 0.0%)
  • UK GDP Estimate YY (Feb) 0.3% vs. Exp. 0.5% (Prev. 0.6%)

 

FX

Turkey’s banking watchdog reduced banks’ forex swap, forward and option transactions limits with foreign entities to 1% from 10%. In other news, Turkey’s Interior Minister resigned from position over the short-notice coronavirus curfew, but the Presidency noted that President Erdogan has not accepted the Interior Minister’s resignation. (Newswires)

 

COMMODITIES

OPEC+ resolved stand-off with Mexico on Sunday and approved its largest ever oil cut in which it agreed to cuts of 9.7mln bpd for May-June in which the draft statement noted that total global oil cuts effective next month will total more than 20mln bpd. Furthermore, Saudi’s Energy Minister stated that OPEC+ effective oil cuts total 12.5mln bpd due to higher output in April and the Azeri Energy Ministry noted that Mexico will reduce its output by 100k bpd from next month and that the US will compensate for Mexico with another 300k bpd, while Russian Energy Minister Novak commented that the new OPEC+ agreement exempts gas condensate production from quotas. (Newswires)

This follows last week’s agreement for OPEC+ to cut overall output by 10mln BPD from May 1st 2020 for 2 months, then 8mln BPD from July to December 2020, followed by 6mln BPD from Jan 2021 to April 2022 and will be subject to review in December 2021, according to Energy Intel. Furthermore, the deal will be valid until the end of 2022, however subject to review in December 2021, while Russia and Saudi Arabia agreed to cut 2.5mln BPD, from the reported 11.0mln baseline. (Newswires)

G20 energy communique was delayed amid following a disagreement between EU and Saudi regarding clean energy. (Newswires)

IEA will announce on Monday oil purchases into reserves that will contribute towards effective oil output cuts, according to sources. (Newswires)

 

US

Federal Reserve took additional action on Thursday to provide up to USD 2.3tln in loans to support the economy and will keep monitoring markets to see if more help is needed, while it will purchase up to USD 600bln in loans through main street lending program aimed at small and midsize businesses using USD 75bln in capital from Treasury. Fed are to begin buying some junk-rated corporate bonds corporate facility to include recently downgraded BB bonds, while it will explore making the Paycheck Protection Programme facility open to non-banks in the future and said the expanded corporate programmes are meant to cover fallen angels that have been downgraded after the start of COVID-19 as well as some high yield ETFs. (Newswires)

NY Fed to purchase USD 30bln Treasuries per day next week (prev. USD 50bln per day this week). (Newswires)

  • US CPI (Mar) M/M -0.4% vs. Exp. -0.3% (Prev. 0.1%). (Newswires)
  • US CPI (Mar) Y/Y 1.5% vs. Exp. 1.6% (Prev. 2.3%)
